text:
Television crime dramas have run up a huge
audience, but their surge in popularity has
come with some unexpected consequences.

Yes, they’ve gotten people interested in
forensic science.

But they’ve also mangled our expectations
of the forensic profession and what’s going
on in the lab.

So today we’re going to enhance… enhance…
enhance… enhance your understanding of what

it’s really like to be a forensic expert
– with a little first-hand account from
our chemical comrade, Dr. Rubidium.

Let’s set the record straight here folks,
forensic science is an incredibly interesting

field to be in, but the reality of the situation
is that if CSI Miami was 100% accurate in

the way they show the science, they’d probably
lose about 100% of their audience.

The fact of the matter is, forensics is about
chemical analysis, and generally speaking,
that takes a lot of patience and concentration…

Real experts know that gathering evidence
and analyzing it in the laboratory is a painstaking
process, with little room for action.

On CSI you’ll find forensic analysts hot
on the criminal’s tail after a quick stint

in the lab, kicking butt while simultaneously
slinging chemistry and a Glock.

For those of you out there excited about forensics,
we hate to break it to you…

your kung-fu classes aren’t going to be
anywhere near as useful as your knowledge

of chromatography or mass spectrometry, or
your ability to keep patiently on task to

make sure you have everything you need before
you whip back to the laboratory after reviewing
the scene of a crime.

“You know before we leave a crime scene
you would go through and go yeah, do we ha

ve check, check, check, and you do things
in a very regimented way because you have

to because you want to make sure you’ve
done everything to the best standards of protocols…

… So it’s hard to have a dramatic scene
where everyone’s running to the car to chase

down the bad guy when you’re in the middle
of a checklist... … there’s none of those

dramatic moments because you’re the dorks
that are doing the checklist, and there’s

some complete other unit that gets to be doing
the dramatic running scene and car chasing
people.
Those are the police.

You get to the be the ones to make sure you
bring enough gloves.”
And it’s not just the crime scene.

Audiences have been spoiled with crime labs
that look more like Mythbusters work-spaces

with dramatic art-house theater lighting than
they do actual chemistry labs.

“And I swear, CSI Miami had the darkest
labs I think I’ve ever seen in my life,

like the outside everyone was clearly blinded
by the sun because everyone’s in sunglasses”

Not to mention the dozens of seemingly omniscient
analytical tools and processes that regurgitate

case-breaking hard evidence at the push of
a button.

“They’re going to inject something into
some machine and it’s going to be this beautiful

print-out - and it’s going to be like, ‘oh
it’s such ‘n’ such that was only manufactured

by blahbadiblah between the years of blahbadiblah
and blah blah.
Oh!

And it’s only currently sold in this specific
location…’ and you’re like, what is

this magical printout you have in front of
you!”

Make no mistake folks, this is a “science”
machine that elucidates plot points, not real
world evidence.

But that doesn’t mean writers don’t try
to be at least a little bit accurate.

Even though they’re dramatized, these television
labs are inspired by the real thing.

But hey, why not try writing in some safety
goggles in next time, or head back to CHEM101.

In real-life crime laboratories you’re going
to find a mix of chemists with very different
specialties and backgrounds.

Toxicology, materials & residue analysis,
and general chemistry tend to dominate the

field of forensics, and it’s usually never
the case that there’s a jack of all trades

expert like NCIS’ Abby Sciuto or CSI’s
Gil Grissom, who somehow both squeezed in
two lifetimes’ worth of science degrees.

Because you have so many different specialists
and a limited amount of equipment to use while

juggling deadlines, you’ll find that forensic
scientists are masters of multitasking and
sharing…

“You have to 
schedule your time and get all of that processing

done and be very multitasking and very methodical
in your approach.

You do the same thing when you’re processing
so you kind of look at like what’s the landscape

look like and plan out when you’ll need
this instrument or this room or this thing,

and you start booking it out because your
working usually with lots of other folks who
are going to need to do the same thing…

But hey now, that doesn’t mean that real
forensics experts aren’t heroes.

You have to remember, while there isn’t
all that action like on television, forensic

scientists make our world a safer place by
using chemistry to help put real criminals

behind bars, while also saving those who are
wrongfully accused.
Now that is some chemical justice.

Thanks for tuning in, and don’t forget to
subscribe before you go.
We’ll catch you next time!
